UML:TaggedValue.value:
The build system for API documentation shall be SHFB (Sandcastle Help File Builder) by Eric Woodruff.
Results shall be in HTML and MSHELP 2.x format compatible with Visual Studio 2017.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Rules which should not be ignored

UML:TaggedValue.value: Derive exceptions from System.Exception or one of the other common base exceptions.
All options under this code analysis section should be enabled (part of Microsoft Managed Recommended Rules).

Following changes
  • CREQ0012: Change constants to have no prefix
  • CREQ0029: A title "Ordering" without content
  • CREQ0070: Title change to SafeHandles
  • CREQ0071: Added rationale for SafeHandles
  • CREQ0103: The Model, and design principles
  • CREQ0105: NUnit Test Framework should be used instead of MSTest
  • CREQ0137: Define pseudo constants (private static readonly variables)
  • CREQ0129: Implementing a Singleton in C#
  • CREQ0130: Critical Sections and subsection
  • CREQ0135: Optional Parameters and subsection
  • CREQ0138: Abstract classes
  • CREQ0142: Null conditional operator, do not use for event handlers
  • CREQ0148: Use of nameof keyword
  • CREQ0149: Don't use named parameters
  • CREQ0150: SafeHandle and DangerousGetHandle
  • CREQ0151: Avoid side effects in construction
  • CREQ0152: Use AccessorBase implementation
  • CREQ0156: Single Responsibility Principle
  • CREQ0158: Virtual protected methods for Events
  • CREQ0159: Don't use Enum.HasFlag
  • CREQ0160: Argument Parameters (boxing/unboxing)
Stream types shall end with the noun Stream.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S1104: Make the field private and encapsulate it in a public property

UML:TaggedValue.value: Source files should have any using statement which is not referenced as being removed.

Variables, methods, fields, types and name spaces shall differ by more than just their case. This allows support for other .NET languages and higher reuse (e.g. Visual Basic .NET is case insensitive, while C# is not).

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S1854: Remove useless assignment to local variable

UML:TaggedValue.value: In NUnit, you should use the [TestCase] attribute where it makes sense to improve test case coverage, without having to repeat significant portions of code. You should limit the maximum number of parameters to 3, to reduce the complexity of the test cases and the code. Rationale: It gets difficult when the number of [TestCase] attributes exceed 8. Still, there is no concrete requirement to limit the number of Test Cases, especially with string type inputs where the number of input variations can be high.
Hungarian notation shall not be used for any non-Windows forms code.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S4143: Verify that setting key/index was intended, value has already been set
Separate Production Code from Test Code

UML:TaggedValue.value: A separate test project shall be created that is in parallel to the production code. Do not mix test code and production code in the same project file. Rationale: All test code, is by definition dead code (it is not used by the framework library) and should not be part of the product. In case that a platform is failing, it is easy to copy the code that performs the tests to the client platform and rerun. For example NUnit 2.6.x has minimum requirements of .NET 2.0, which is less than modern code, and so requires minimal, if at all, extra installation to run the tests.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S3966: Refactor to ensure code is only disposed once

UML:TaggedValue.value: Do not dispose an object twice. This may lead to an ObjectDisposedException.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Aesthetic Rules which Should be Enabled

UML:TaggedValue.value:
ReSharper is a commercial tool and provides lint like functionality. Useful from ReSharper is the documentation explaining the reasoning for errors found.
It can find typical coding design issues (usage of virtual methods in a constructor) as well as recommendations that can make code more readable.
When providing overloaded methods, try and keep all overloaded methods adjacent to one another. This allows for code to be found quicker.

A best practice from Visual Basic (since version 3!) is to use Hungarian notation for the identification of GUI objects. This makes it easy to identify the type of control being references, as well as to sort the controls.
Objects in a Windows Forms project shall be prefixed with the object type (starting in lower case), followed by a more detailed description of the object.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Prefer async/await over BeginXXX and EndXXX

UML:TaggedValue.value: The usage of Task and the async and await keywords is much more readable than the usage of BeginXXX and EndXXX Libraries targeted for .NET 4.0 and earlier cannot use the async and await keywords (only formally introduced and working in .NET 4.5).

UML:ClassifierRole.name: IDE0041: Null check can be simplified (object is null)

UML:TaggedValue.value:
Each project shall have its own GlobalSuppression.cs file, which will be used to maintain a list of suppressions. This file can be automatically generated by Visual Studio when suppressing a warning or a message in a file. The suppression attribute shall be modified so that:
  • The Target property is removed
  • The Member property is removed
  • The Justification property is updated.
There is no way in .NET FX to enable suppression for all projects.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S4070: Non-flag enums should not be marked with FlagsAttribute

UML:TaggedValue.value: SonarLint often shows this warning, when the intent of the enum (the values present in the field) are clearly a bit field, even if not used as such. Keeping the FlagsAttribute increases readability at makes it obvious the purpose of the enum.

Sonar Lint for Visual Studio (as of writing version 4.13) should be used in projects. It is an Open Source tool with support by Microsoft, working with Visual Studio 2017 and later.
SonarLint should be installed as a Visual Studio extension, not as a NuGet package for individual projects.

The use of partial classes should generally be avoided. Some instances where partial classes are useful:
  • Use with code generators, where a user might provide their implementation on top, while IDE helpers keep the generated code separated (such an example is WinForms).
  • P/Invoke, where the top level class is used like a namespace (e.g. Kernel32) and it is expected to contain a lot of nested classes and structs.
Using it in the design for normal classes shows that the class is likely too large and should be refactored into smaller components.

The constructor of a class should do as little work as possible, generally only initializing the object. Doing more can be CPU expensive for the application. Do NOT:
  • perform CPU intensive operations in the constructor
  • load files in the constructor
Do:
  • Initialize variables only
Rationale: Initializing a class should not block, so as to not block GUI operations or cause unexpected delays in application code. It is not possible to implement asynchronous constructors.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S1118: Add a protected constructor or the static keyword to the class delcaration
S2259: Variable is null on at least one execution path

UML:TaggedValue.value: This is a probable bug, that could lead to a NullReferenceException. It should be analyzed and fixed.

Avoid named parameters in function/constructor calls C# allows the use of named parameters when calling functions to improve readability. This is especially true for boolean inputs. However, there are other reasons against. Rationale:
  • Using named parameters makes reviews in Web Browsers (such as Crucible, BitBucket, Gerrit) more difficult when trying to find the correct function being reviewed. MSDN lists each overload showing the type, not the parameter name. To find the documentation for a specific function using MSDN is easier without named parameters.
  • If a parameter name changes, but not the signature, software will no longer compile.
An exception to this rule might be defining attributes in code for:
  • Code analysis warning/message suppression
  • Test case attributes specifying the test name or other properties

The definition of events should use the Generic EventHandler<EventArgs> form. public event EventHandler<MyEventArgs> MyEvent; Rationale: See MSDN CA1003. Before .NET Framework 2.0, in order to pass custom information to the event handler, a new delegate had to be declared that specified a class that was derived from the System.EventArgs class. This is no longer true in .NET Framework 2.0, which introduced the System.EventHandler<TEventArgs> delegate. This generic delegate allows any class that is derived from EventArgs to be used together with the event handler.

Remove using statements within the namespace which aren't referenced anywhere. Example: using System; using System.Text; There is no code using System.Text, so it should be removed. Warning: In SonarLint 4.13.0.11687 there are two bugs:
  • using System.Linq will be warned even if there is the usage of the select keyword. Removing this will break compilation.
  • using <namespace> will be warned even if there is a MAML documentation statement referencing the namespace. Removing this will break documentation generation.

False positives should generally not be suppressed, so that fixes in the analyzer can be found. For example, SonarLint 4.12 has false positives for the usage of null parameters, that were fixed in 4.13 which shows more likely errors. For cases where it must be suppressed, the Justification should contain the test "False Positive, reason" and be applied at the scope where the false positive has minimal effect.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S1939: Interface implements another interface and so can be removed
CA2213: Disposable fields should be disposed

UML:TaggedValue.value:
Applications and Frameworks should follow Domain Driven Design, separating Application, Business / Model, Storage and Infrastructure into separate layers, potentially separate assemblies for strict separation.
Each class in each layer should be designed for testability.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: IDE1005: Event Handler Invocation can be simplified
Don't use Optional Parameters for Public API

UML:TaggedValue.value:
Optional parameters shall not be used for public API's. Rationale:
  • Changing a method signature using optional parameters can cause existing clients to break. That leads to breaking backwards compatibility.
  • When avoiding the backwards compatibility issue by adding a new overload, an ambiguity on determining the correct method may then result.
For more information, see the link: http://haacked.com/archive/2010/08/10/versioning-issues-with-optional-arguments.aspx/ An exception to this rule would be to have similar API to what is provided in the .NET framework (e.g. streams in .NET Core 5).
Do not use string operations based on StringComparison.InvariantCulture in most cases. One of the few exceptions is when you are persisting linguistically meaningful but culturally agnostic data.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S1066: Collapsible "if" statements should be merged

UML:TaggedValue.value:
Collapsing if statements may make it more difficult to read the purpose of checks.
In some instances of code, two if statements may be desirable, if the intended checks are independent of each other.
Often projects have reasons for using a different naming style, or legacy code. Enabling this message may result in a lot of false positives, making it more difficult to find real issues.

If a singleton should be required, one of the following design patterns should be used. http://csharpindepth.com/Articles/General/Singleton.aspx Be careful of the usage of keywords such as volatile, readonly as given in the specific example. There may be the possibility of implementing subtle race conditions if used incorrectly. PROs of the static constructor implementation:
  1. Less code than double-check locking => less error-prone (the shorter the code, the fewer the bugs J).
  2. It is thread-safe without making use of locking mechanisms + allows CLR optimizations => from a performance perspective, it is more efficient.

Use the String.Compare and String.CompareTo methods to sort strings, not to check for equality. Use an overload of the String.Equals method to test whether two strings are equal. Do not use an overload of the String.Compare or CompareTo method and test for a return value of zero to determine whether two strings are equal.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: CA1065: Do not raise exceptions in unexpected locations
S2486: Handle the exception or explain why it can be ignored
S3925: Update implementation of ISerializable to conform to recommended pattern

UML:TaggedValue.value: The name of the class should be a noun, or a noun phrase, following the general naming rules given above (PascalCasing, no underscores, etc.).

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Using Generics to Avoid Boxing and Unboxing

UML:TaggedValue.value:
Datastructures should use Generics instead of the base object type, especially when value types can be used.
The operation of copying a value type into the reference type object is expensive, involving a copy operation when converting from the value type to the reference type.

The CodeAnalysis plugin is available with paid versions of Microsoft Visual Studio as well as the Community Editions.
CodeAnalysis is a lint tool that highlights common errors based on Microsoft Coding Guidelines.
It is found in the menu Analyze -> Run CodeAnalysis on Solution.
Below are some common error codes considered as a problem during development, but by no means all. Each error code should be analysed on a case-by-case basis and determined if it is a problem or not. Almost all issues are considered an issue and should be fixed.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S1871: Merge this branch or change one of the implementations

UML:TaggedValue.value: Indicates often a copy/paste bug. Either an else/if block or a switch case has identical implementations. They should be merged, or corrected (if it was a copy/paste bug).

Production code and code bases which should be maintained over a longer period of time should not use string interpolation. String interpolation can be used in projects where the language is expected to remain constant, for example, unit test projects and logging. Rationale: String interpolation does not allow extracting the strings into resources for Internationalization. As projects grow and are used by more teams across the world internationalization is important.

Common abbreviations that are two characters should be both upper case. Abbreviations of three characters or more should be capitalized, with the remaining characters being lower case. Example: The namespace MyCompany.IO is preferred over MyCompany.Io.

Following changes
  • CREQ0215: Allow P/Invoke for partial classes
  • CREQ0336: Single character variables
  • CREQ0337: Read Only Properties

Overloading is having two methods of the same name with different signatures. All overloaded methods in the class should return the same type (or be void). IL does allow overloaded methods to return different types, this should be avoided for compatibility. Overloaded methods should be semantically the same.

A lock object should be marked as readonly and initialized as an object in the constructor. This prevents a lock object from being reassigned, ensuring that the lock object remains constant throughout the lifetime of a class. Rationale: Often a collection object is also its own lock to synchronize modification to it. If in an add/remove operation we lock the collection, but in a Reset method we were to simply create a new instance, current locks are invalid and may lead to obscure race conditions. By making a dedicated lock object, we avoid this problem (CREQ0132), but if the collection were marked readonly, the compiler would complain if the collection object were to be reassigned. If for legacy reasons it's not easy to create a new lock, simply assigning objects as readonly which are used as locks may help to identify unidentified bugs.
WPF Projects should use the MVVM model. The Model and View Model should be testable.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Extending Objects and the Open/Closed Principle

UML:TaggedValue.value: New project should strive to conform to this set of coding standards where it's mandated.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S2292: Make this an auto-implemented property
S3928: Use a constructor overload that allows more meaningful exception error message

UML:TaggedValue.value: All options under this code analysis section should be enabled (part of Microsoft Managed Recommended Rules).
Event Argument objects should derive from System.EventArgs and end with EventArgs in the name.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Exception in Signature to OnXXXEvent Protected Method

UML:TaggedValue.value: Avoid defining an empty constructor for structs. When a struct is defined on the heap, it is initialized with default values (e.g. zero), making initialization of the struct faster.
Exceptions should end with the noun Exception. Example: MyErrorException
Use string operations that are based on StringComparison.CurrentCulture when you display output to the user.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S4144: Update method that the implementation is not identical to another method

UML:TaggedValue.value: This is often a copy/paste bug, and indicates unintended behavior.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S2583: Change condition so that it does not always evaluate to false; some subsequent code is never executed

UML:TaggedValue.value: A factory can be used to create an object and then to immediately use a method of that object to perform a long running operation if required. A factory method can be easily refactored to be an asynchronous method if required, returning a Task instead.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S3217: Explicit conversion of foreach loops should not be used
S125: Remove the commented out code

UML:TaggedValue.value: Commented out code usually indicates a refactoring and the code is either outdated, or is a TODO element. One should remove it if it is no longer relevant, and rely on revision control systems to know what changed. Warning: SonarLint often marks this as a false positive if it sees some particular characters, such as ;, and may need to be suppressed as needed.

Spaces shall be used for indentation, with 4 spaces being equivalent to 1 tab. Rationale: A single tab is typically 8 spaces. This makes spacing excessive. One can configure an IDE to interpret a tab as 4 spaces but is tedious and manual work. By using spaces, it can be guaranteed consistent results regardless of the IDE (or diff tool) in use. Other projects might have used 2 or 3 spaces for tabs. Using 2 spaces provides insufficient indentation to identify problematic code due to heavily nested statements. 3 spaces is discarded as it's not aligned with any of the default tabbing.

Do not use Debug.Assert. Rationale: Using Debug.Assert will raise a window to the user for extra debug information by default. This results in tests that can't be automated if a Debug.Assert fires, because the program will generally halt waiting for the user to continue.

Following changes
  • CREQ0162: String comparisons
  • CREQ0175: Design patterns for testing
  • CREQ0177: Debug and conditional checks
  • CREQ0181: Common implementation, buffer range checks
  • CREQ0182: Editor Config file
  • CREQ0183: Sort usings
  • CREQ0185: Don't use static usings.
  • CREQ0190: Organizing test code
  • CREQ0195-202: NUnit Asserts and Fluent style
  • CREQ0203: Visual Studio Analyzers, codes and rationale
  • CREQ0235: Overloads should be adjacent
  • CREQ0293: New section on types
  • CREQ0297: New section about classes
  • CREQ0300: New section about properties
  • CREQ0305: String interpolation
  • CREQ0306: Rule Suppression
  • CREQ0313: Synchronization Primitives

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S1135: Complete the task associated with the TODO comment

UML:TaggedValue.value: Programmers add 'TODO' indicating that functionality is not complete. These warnings should be present and visible to the user so they can be acted upon.

New in Visual Studio 2019 16.3 is the ability to suppress error messages in the IDE via the .editorconfig file. This should be avoided. Even though this is a central location for the suppression of rules, it applies to the editor only, not the build system.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: IDE0016: Null check can be simplified (Exceptions on Null)

UML:TaggedValue.value: Classes should be marked as static if it only contains static methods and properties. This marks the class as non-instantiable. If this is not possible, then a class should have a private default constructor defined that marks it as non-instantiable.

There are two aspects to coding standards:
  • Guidelines to assist developers in reading and identifying code, especially in teams of two or more developers. This assists developers in better understanding the intentions of others.
  • Applying design patterns. By documenting lessons learned in previous projects, the application of design patterns can improve code readability, design and reduce the chance of defects by less experienced developers.
Where possible, coding standards should also include rationale, to help assist developers in understanding why such a coding standard exists and how it is intended to benefit the project. These coding standards use the text Rationale to explain any reasoning behind decisions in implementation. This also encourages developers to decide on a more appropriate guideline, or to decide the circumstances under which a guideline should be applied. It also challenges the author of such a guideline to justify the means for a restriction on the writing of code, which may lead to a more solid foundation of the guidelines, or an update improving the guidelines themselves. Keywords and coding words are in bold, such as return, IEnumerable, etc.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Never Use Referenced Parameters for output

UML:TaggedValue.value: Avoid the usage of referenced parameters (usage of the ref or out keyword) for operations that do not complete immediately. Rationale: These operations cannot be easily rewritten in an asynchronous programming model using either BeginXXX/EndXXX or Task. Even when doing so requires an implementation where the asynchronous methods look and behave differently to the synchronous methods.

Software design should use Inversion of Control where appropriate to allow testability. Rationale: A class for implementing hardware diagnostics would have a class that necessarily requires information from hardware through specialized drivers. A business logic class might raise events depending on the data that is obtained. Testing can be challenging, especially if it requires specific hardware, or even more so difficult in error use cases. By using an interface to abstract the hardware and allowing the business logic class to program against an interface instead of a specific implementation, a test case can be written to simulate error conditions without the need for specific hardware.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S1125: Remove the unnecessary boolean literals

UML:TaggedValue.value: If your object is long lived, but the subscriber of the event is short lived, implement the IDispose interface on the subscriber object, so that removal of the event is controlled. This is a very subtle memory leak in the .NET framework that has memory impact (the objects cannot be freed due to a strong reference from the no longer referenced short lived subscriber object to the long lived referenced object). There is also a potential performance impact, that the no longer referenced subscriber will still have its event called, even though it's no longer required.
Events in assemblies should generally be a verb and end with Event in the name. A general exception to this rule are Windows Forms controls.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S2347: Remove this silly bit operation

UML:TaggedValue.value: Properties should be allowed to be set in any order, and should be stateless with respect to other properties. Rationale: A property looks like a variable to the programmer, and they expect it to behave like a variable. Only when a specific method is called, would the class enter a particular state that then uses these variables. Until then, the state of the properties shouldn't matter.

There is an option in Visual Studio 2013 and later to ensure that System.* namespaces are sorted first:
  • Options -> Text Editor -> C# -> Advanced
  • Organize Usings -> Place 'System' directives first when sorting usings
Rationale: Sorting in alphabetical order helps to quickly identify the using statements.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S3458: Remove this empty case clause
S1168: Return an empty collection instead of null
IDE0018: Variable declaration can be Inlined

UML:TaggedValue.value: An object is instantiated that implements IDIsposable. That object is never disposed. Dispose the object to fix the warning.

This applies to private members, methods as well as constants. If the value is private but it is not read.
The member, method or constant should be removed.

Do not use the feature using static Class; Rationale: Many code reviews are done within WebEditors, such as Gerrit, BitBucket, GitHub, etc. Excessive usage of this feature may make it difficult more to know the source of the function being called, and can lead to a loss of quality during the code review.
The methods being tested in the EXE should be public, to make it easier to test without having to resort to reflection and other difficult to read constructs.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Using System (and non-project references) Inside the Namespace

UML:TaggedValue.value: The using statements of the System.* namespace should occur within the namespace. They should be first and sorted in alphabetical order.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S907: Remove this use of goto

UML:TaggedValue.value: For all those who remember spaghetti code and the 1980's

Classes should be designed to perform one task. Example: See also the Dispose pattern, separating managed and unmanaged behavior. Rationale: The Single Responsibility Principle increases testability, maintainability and readability of code.

Avoid using the Enum.HasFlag in performance critical code. It will box twice, cause at least two memory allocations for each check. As an alternative, do bit comparisons. myEnum.HasFlag(MyEnum.EnumValue); results in boxing when converting the value type myEnum to a reference type, and then again converting MyEnum.EnumValue to a reference type: // else if (((Enum)(object)myEnum).HasFlag((Enum)(object)MyEnum.EnumValue)) IL_0106: ldloc.0 IL_0107: box MyEnum IL_010c: ldc.i4.2 IL_010d: box MyEnum IL_0112: call instance bool [mscorlib]System.Enum::HasFlag(class [mscorlib]System.Enum) // (no C# code) IL_0117: brfalse.s IL_0126 As a reference, see https://stackoverflow.com/questions/7368652/what-is-it-that-makes-enum-hasflag-so-slow

The first element(s) of the namespace should represent the organization, followed by the technology, then further the feature and design. Example:
  • RJCP.Log.Dlt
  • RJCP.Windows.Forms
Software shall take extra care in implementation of the Dispose pattern, as recommended by Microsoft.

Example - String Equality: Assert.That(myString, Is.EqualTo("string")); Do not use Assert.That(myString.Equals("string"), Is.True); Example - StartsWith: Assert.That(myString, Does.StartWith("str")); Do not use Assert.That(myString.StartsWith("str"), Is.True); Example - EndsWith: Assert.That(myString, Does.EndWith("ing")); Do not use Assert.That(myString.EndsWith("ing"), Is.True); Example - Substrings: Assert.That(myString, Contains.SubString("rin")); Example - Regular Expressions: Assert.That(myString, Is.StringMatching("s.*g")); Example - String Length: Assert.That(myString, Has.Length.EqualTo(5)); Example - Compound Check with RegEx: Assert.That(myString, Has.Length.GreaterThan(2).And.Not.Matches(".*s$"));
There are many ways to write testable code, some listed in this section.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S1206: Class overrides GetHashCode and should override Equals

UML:TaggedValue.value: When providing an implementation of Equals, one must always provide an implementation of the GetHashCode method. The GetHashCode method is used by .NET framework datastructures, such as Dictionary and HashSet for sorting values. Users would expect that if two objects are equal, then their hash code are also equal. Note: The reverse is not true, if two hash codes are equal, the objects are not necessarily equal.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S3246: Add the 'in' keyword to make it contravariant

UML:TaggedValue.value: If you have more than three operational parameters that you want to test, then instead of using the [TestCase] attribute, you should design a test class and manually program testing the various combinations.

The .NET implementation of a stream doesn't support simultaneous reading and writing from a stream. If this is required, explicit implementation of BeginRead and EndRead are required. If your stream is full duplex, that is, reading and writing are expected to work in parallel and are independent of each other, deadlocks may occur when using the default implementation. These deadlocks are by design in Microsoft's implementation For more information, see: http://www.codeproject.com/Tips/575618/Avoiding-Deadlocks-with-System-IO-Stream-BeginRead

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S2328: Refactor GetHashCode to not reference mutable fields

UML:TaggedValue.value: .NET implementations such as Dictionary and HashSet use the GetHashCode function when sorting and inserting the object into their data structure. If the GetHashCode were mutable, this would cause errors in those data structures (the objects might not be found, sorting breaks). To fix this, parameters within GetHashCode should reference readonly properties only.

This is not available in C# 7.0 and so will fail when compiling with Visual Studio 2017.
The usage of lambdas should be used in preference to local functions, to make it obvious the use of anonymous methods.
Many languages have supported nested classes, multiple inheritance, nested functions. Practice has shown that this is often abused and can lead to difficult to maintain code.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: User Output should use Culture-Sensitive formatting

UML:TaggedValue.value: Use culture-sensitive formatting to display non-string data, such as numbers and dates, in a user interface. Use formatting with the invariant culture to persist non-string data in string form.

Using the nameof keyword (available in C# 5.0, VS2012 and later) avoids incorrect spelling of method and parameter names (errors thus resulting in compilation failures). IDEs also typically support refactoring of variable renaming resulting in automatic updates to the arguments of nameof, reducing effort. Rationale: Using the nameof keyword avoid incorrect spelling of names (that would otherwise result in compilation failures), and assists with renaming of variables. It can be used for exception parameter names, or in reflection for names of methods and properties (when using Invoke).
Exceptions should not be returned as a return value or parameter instead of being thrown.
The module variable shall have a prefix, followed by the name in PascalCasing with a capital letter at the beginning.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S3241: Change return type to void, not a single caller uses the value

UML:TaggedValue.value: Private methods are clearly intended for use only within their own scope. When such methods return values that are never used by any of their callers, then clearly there is no need to actually make the return, and it should be removed in the interests of efficiency and clarity.

Consider naming read-only properties that describe state or testing a feature by prefixing the property with Is or Has. Example:
  • IsConnected
  • HasFeature
The read/write property if something is enabled or not would be Enabled and not IsEnabled as it's also writable.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Do Not Synchronize on Operating System Real-Time Clock

UML:TaggedValue.value:
Never base sleep periods based on the Operating System Clock. Always use Operating System primitives that are based on the internal monotonic clock that is not at all related to the CMOS real-time clock. Rationale: The real-time clock is never guaranteed to be monotonic (e.g. Daylight savings can cause the clock to roll back), and never guaranteed to be a measure of real time of when your process is running. There are many situations that can distort the clock such as:
  • Time synchronization services, such as Windows Time, or NTP
  • Daylight Savings changes
  • System Suspend and Resume
Applications and Framework libraries should follow an appropriate design pattern, that is suited for testability, even if relatively small.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: IDE0031: Null check can be simplified (null propagation)

UML:TaggedValue.value: Variable names should avoid abbreviations or contractions of identifiers where possible and be correctly spelled. GOOD: TraceServer BAD: TraceSvr GOOD: CommandLine BAD: CmdLine

Be careful with methods that have a signature such as: Console.WriteLine(string format, params object[] arguments); Using it such as: Console.WriteLine("Values: {0} {1}", 1, 2); will result in boxing the integer value types to reference types. There are two things that happen here:
  1. An array is automatically created by the compiler for arguments
  2. The value types are boxed into reference types and then stored into the array
It is not at all efficient like C, where values are pushed onto the stack, but instead type safe and cannot cause stack corruption.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: CA2214: Do not call overridable methods in constructors

UML:TaggedValue.value:
A constructor should not call a virtual method from itself, as this can lead to undefined behaviour for derived classes. Refactoring/Redesign of the class is required.
If a derived class overrides the virtual method, and that virtual method then depends on variables of the derived class, its behaviour is undefined. That is because of the order in which the constructors are called.
The base class constructor is called first, which if then uses a virtual method, is executed on a class whose constructor has not yet been called, thus resulting in undefined behaviour.

Comments within the code should be avoided, instead a preference to more descriptive naming of variables and method that describes the code in the same way. Similarly, MAML documentation of internal and private methods should only be provided if it brings value, with a preference instead for descriptive naming of the method and parameters of the method. Rationale: Providing documentation for simple methods increases workload and burden, allowing for a higher probability later of incorrect documentation should the code change (as it's often documentation is not updated when code is updated).

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Read Only and Write Only Properties

UML:TaggedValue.value: Properties may be read only. When writing them, they could raise an exception indicating that it is read only. The appropriate exception is InvalidOperationException. Properties should not be write-only. Replace such properties as methods.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Organizing Class Constructors with Default Parameters

UML:TaggedValue.value: Consider providing exception properties for programmatic access to extra information (besides the message string) relevant to the exception.

Boxing is the process of taking a value type, allocating memory on the heap and copying the value to the new memory so that there is now a reference to it. There is the explicit instruction in IL called box that does this.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S1144: Remove the unused private field

UML:TaggedValue.value: Code quality scan tools should be used during the development. For each tool, some common conditions are highlighted that should not occur.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S2344: Enumeration type names should not have 'Flags' or 'Enum' suffixes

UML:TaggedValue.value:
This rule can be ignored, it doesn't necessarily improve readability.
Often, code that uses P/Invoke names enumerations as such to be consistent with WinAPI.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Assembly Public Documentation for Framework Components

UML:TaggedValue.value: XML documentation shall be provided for all API framework components.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Usage of Coding Standards for C#
S108: Either remove or fill this block of code
Prefer Return Values over ref and out

UML:TaggedValue.value: Prefer the usage of returning values from a function than the usage of referenced parameters (those with the keyword ref and out). The usage of out is suitable for situations where users are used to similar situations with existing frameworks, e.g. bool TryGetValue(string key, out object value) Rationale: This promotes functional style programming which is easier to verify. Rationale: In newer versions of the language, you can return Tuples.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: IDE0068: Use the recommended dispose pattern to ensure that object is disposed on all paths with a using statement or try/finally

UML:TaggedValue.value: An object is disposed on some paths, but not all paths.
Do not create exceptions that can be thrown in debug mode but not release mode. To identify run-time errors during the development phase, use Debug Assert instead.

The suppression attribute may be applied to a member or a class.
  • The Justification property shall be provided
  • The Member and Target properties are by default not provided.
A suppression can be applied to a class for multiple members, but the suppression should be as concise as possible (i.e. at the most specific member, with the smallest scope). Thus, when applied to a class, it may be required to provide the Member property for a suppression. An example of this is S4136, adjacent methods, where the suppression would need to apply for all overloads of a member. Example, Member Suppression on a Class: [System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.SuppressMessage("Minor Code Smell", "S4136:Method overloads should be grouped together", Justification = "Code organized by functional group (byte/char)", Scope = "member", Target = "~M:RJCP.Diagnostic.ConsoleReader.Read")] public class ConsoleReader : Stream When applied to the class, all the Read methods are suppressed, but the Write methods are not.

Unmanaged handles should be abstracted using a new class deriving from the SafeHandle object. Rationale: SafeHandles correctly implement reference counting, especially when using P/Invoke so that in case of unexpected errors (stack overflow, memory exceptions, thread abortion, etc.) the reference counter is still properly decremented avoiding memory leaks.
Interfaces should follow the same rules as the Class, but always begin with the capital letter 'I' (i).

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Type Name in the Class Type

UML:TaggedValue.value:
Naming of new classes should follow the naming guidelines of MSDN (TBD: Reference). Such examples are:
  • class MyStream : Stream
  • class MyEventArgs : EventArgs
  • class MyException : Exception
  • class MyAttribute : Attribute
This is different to Hungarian notation where the type name is abbreviated and placed first.

Avoid whereever possible the use of nullable value types, like int?. Rationale: It has been discussed that the null value is probably the biggest programming mistake made in history. Making a value type now a reference type that can be null increases the complexity of software and adds a new failure mode.

By applying the model approach, as discussed in the section for Design Patterns makes it much easier to unit test. Rationale: Applying tests to a model promotes a better design and software architecture. Methods are smaller to make it easier to write unit test code for. Smaller and better defined methods reduce cyclomatic complexity reducing the chance of defects in software and making code easier to read.

Software design should use the Factory pattern to allow a test case to generate their own test objects for mocking. Rationale: By using the factory pattern, the "Program" can initialize factories required for real work. Factories should implement an interface that a test program can write their own factory to replace functionality for mocking. For example, a factory can create a class that can serialize an object to disk. A test program might want to replace this factory with its own, so that when the main application serializes to disk, the test class generated by the test factory raises a file system exception, otherwise exceptionally difficult for all Operating Systems when done as an integration test.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Small and Simple Applications - The Model folder

UML:TaggedValue.value: Small applications, even Console applications should separate the presentation layer (console output, or Windows forms code) against the logic that makes decisions. The logic that defines the behavior of the application should be in the Model folder. Rationale: As an example, consider the Windows Forms application that is relatively small to simply parse a file and then to output into a different file. If the parsing is implemented using a model approach with a well thought out design at the beginning, converting the Windows application to also support a console mode is simple - a set sequence of commands are executed in a small function to read the file, parse the file, then save the converted file. If done correctly, the effort is very small. Rationale: Unit Testing support is increased significantly by separating the GUI from the model. By having logic in the model, it is much easier to target unit tests and ensure that the system behaves as expected. The presentation layer is smaller and only needs to deal with logic related to the GUI or the presentation to the user.

All software designs, from small to large should consider an architecture model that is suitable for the application being developed.
A small application should have a minimal model, typically the presentation layer separating from logic that manages the data.
GUI applications should consider the Model-View-Presenter (Windows Forms) or Model-View-View-Model (Windows Presentation Foundation). Whether an application uses a supporting framework, such as the Entity framework is a matter of expected scope and side of the application. If a model is too complicated for the application, more work is spent in building the infrastructure than implementing the relatively small feature scope. Too simple a model, and the more complicated it is to maintain that application among larger teams.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S4136: Method overloads should be adjacent

UML:TaggedValue.value:
When writing code, all methods of the same name with overloads should be adjacent to one another.
This makes it easier to find code, and functionally should be strongly related to one another.

Following changes
  • CREQ0058: Renamed to blocking behaviour
  • CREQ0327: Document using factories to easily convert o async
  • CREQ0330: Async programming model

Do not use the InternalsVisibleTo attribute to allow testability of internal objects. Rationale: The InternalsVisibleTo attribute is a powerful and convenient mechanism to implement a test case. Having production code refer to test code however, is unnatural (the test code should refer to production code it tests). It also implies directly a change to the assembly being tested if multiple assemblies for test would be desired and causes issues with strongly named binaries (also introducing reversed dependencies and increased build complexity).
Information for this section is derived from Microsoft's Best Practices for strings, found at https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/standard/base-types/best-practices-strings

UML:ClassifierRole.name: IDE0029: Null check can be simplfied (null coalescing)

UML:TaggedValue.value: Should an analyzer be provided in a project, the suppression of rules shall be done using the project ruleset.
An class managing unmanaged resources should generally be sealed, so it can't be inherited from.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Overload MyCollection<T> Comparison methods with IEqualityComparer<T>

UML:TaggedValue.value:
Singletons should be generally avoided, or they are used sparingly.
A singleton generally only makes sense if that class should, by design, only be instantiated once in the entire application. Framework / reusable components generally don't need singleton classes.
A singleton makes sense for application specific classes, such as holding application state or configuration (as for example, the main design pattern of WPF). This saves the object having to be passed in various places in the application model layer.

GhostDoc makes it considerably simpler to write comments for API methods with (Ctrl-Shift-D).
As code may be moved to a framework component at any time, it is important the API documentation is correct and understandable.
Most recent versions however require a license.

Sometimes it is necessary to perform checks in code, but disable them for release mode for performance reasons. Debug mode should perform extra checking that ensures consistency within the program (such as a "checked" build).

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S101: Rename class to match pascal casing rules

UML:TaggedValue.value: Renaming classes may break API, this should be checked during the code review.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S3358: Extract this nested ternary operation

UML:TaggedValue.value: SonarLint has determined that there are nested ternary operators. The readability of the code is made much more difficult because of this, and the intent of the code can be misunderstood.

Pragmas should not be used for disabling warnings, unless there is no other way. Where possible, suppress warnings through attributes. Rationale: It is easy to write tools to parse through assemblies using reflection to find attributes, even for binaries. Pragma's only exist at the source level.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Ordering of Parameters of Overloaded Methods
CA1404: Call GetLastError immediately after P/Invoke

UML:TaggedValue.value: It is important that Marshal.GetLastWin32Error() is called immediately after a P/Invoke, so that the error code determined is well defined, not based on any other function call.

Do not raise exceptions in the get field of a property. Instead return a default value. The only exception to this are exceptions of type InvalidOperationException and derived types (e.g. also ObjectDisposedException).

Unit Testing should be performed on the main executable as well as on any assemblies that are being used. The major benefits of unit testing for design are:
  • Early refactoring of the software to allow for a clean design that can be unit tested. This reduces the size of the functions, reducing the cyclomatic complexity.
  • Allow early capture of breaking changes, either to framework functionality or classes that are used in other locations.
  • Check functionality again after refactoring
  • Provide documentation in the form of code on how a class is expected to be used, by the way that a Unit test manipulates it.
Advantages of Unit Testing for cross development are:
  • Identify differences between operating systems and their behavior, and ensure the behavior of a class is consistent regardless of the Operating System.
  • Allow for better planning and quicker porting of software to new Operating Systems or frameworks.
Portability is all the more important especially for supporting multiple Operating Systems.
  • There are always subtle differences between the actual operating systems being used. For example, networking on Windows XP might return different results than networking on Windows 7 due to the differences in the underlying network libraries.
  • The Mono Framework on Linux is changing at a rapid pace, especially with the .NET core being open sourced. It is easy to determine for the target platform if the system is likely to work, or if there is missing functionality, or a change in new functionality (especially through the PlatformNotSupportedException).
  • Run unit tests, via the NUnit test binary, to identify issues early in an automatic way.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Difference between VSIX and NuGet Analyzers

UML:TaggedValue.value:
Use a VSIX analyzer in your solution if the warnings and messages should be available while developing. VSIX analyzers do not affect the build in any way.
Use a NuGet analyzer as part of your project if such rules should be made where warnings and errors can abort the build process (enforcing rules during the build). This is a much stricter model. There is no way to enable NuGet analyzers for all projects in a .NET Desktop solution.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S3869: Refactor code to remove SafeHandle.DangerousGetHandle

UML:TaggedValue.value: The usage of DangerousGetHandle is problematic as there is no reference counting or memory management. Should an exception occur at any time (including unexpected exceptions, such as aborting threads), handles might not be properly freed. There is also the possibility that the handle obtained is freed at any time by the object it was obtained from, thus resulting in crashes with Native code. This is a difficult topic, and should be avoided where ever possible.
The usage of appropriate abbreviations should be used where they are common in the computing domain. Example: Dns, Xml, IP, IO, Gui, Http

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S3889: Remove use of Thread.Resume and Thread.Suspend

UML:TaggedValue.value: Use other synchronization primitives, such as ManualResetEvent, etc. to properly control when threads are paused and resumed. These methods should never be used.

Do not use culture-sensitive formatting to persist numeric data or date and time data in string form.
Comparison and casing behavior in .NET changes when the culture changes. This happens when an application executes on a computer that has a different culture than the computer on which the application was developed, or when the executing thread changes its culture.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S3453: This class can't be instantiated, make it's constructor public
S2346: Flags enumerations zero-value members should be named 'None'

UML:TaggedValue.value:
Often it makes sense to name the zero-value members of an enumeration something else. This is often done in the case of bit fields, where a zero value is equivalent to having a bit disabled (e.g. the default value).
This rule doesn't necessarily improve readability.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Casing of Parameters and Stack Variables Naming

UML:TaggedValue.value: Names of private variables (variables defined on the stack of a method, or naming of parameters in a method) shall follow camelCasing with the initial letter being lower case.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Using Project References Inside the Namespace

UML:TaggedValue.value: The using statements should occur within the namespace. They should occur last, be in alphabetical order. They should not reference the namespace in which they reside. Rationale: Some of the software used may be exported as Open Source (see https://github.com/jcurl/serialportstream). In this case, to ensure that the namespaces are separated to avoid any possible conflicts with open source, the root namespace is changed to suit that of the project (RJCP.IO.Ports renamed to NEWPROJ.IO.Ports). The number of internal reference changes is minimal.

There shall be no warnings generated during the build process for Release for API documentation for framework components.
There shall be no warnings or errors generated when building using the current version of SHFB.

If the project build system supports contracts, then contracts should be used.
Contracts allow internal and private methods to state assumptions, such as methods will not be called with null values. Debug mode can throw exceptions if a contract is violated (so that unit tests may find issues faster, rather than ignoring the problem), and static analysis tools may highlight code paths were contracts may be violated.
THe advantage is that code states specifically what is intended and the checks are removed in release mode to allow for better performance.
Microsoft contracts needs specific set up and tools for binary rewriting in release mode.
Unit tests should therefore run in both release mode and debug mode (with and without contracts enabled).

For test cases that have complex types of inputs, which can be reused across multiple test cases, the attribute [TestCaseSource(source)] can be used. The source parameter is the name of the function which provides the source test data. Use the nameof() operator instead of a string to provide the name of the function. The method providing the source must be static, to be compatible with NUnit 2 and NUnit 3. Do not use non-static methods for providing source data.

The coding style attempts to provide as much information as possible on a single screen to help avoid errors associated with complexity.
  • Reduce the amount of whitespace on the screen, so that each method should ideally fit within a single screen. If a method is longer, then the cyclomatic complexity is likely too high.
  • Make it visually easier to identify where a method starts and then stops.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Initialization of Properties that are Read Only

UML:TaggedValue.value: In newer versions of .NET do not provide a private setter if that property is only set in the constructor. Example: public int MyProperty { get; } = 42; Rationale: This is equivalent to readonly properties, and prevents code from setting the properties when they shouldn't.

It's recommended to use the generic version in preference of the non-generic derived event handler. None-the-less, if a non-generic event handler is used, it shall end in the noun EventHandler. See Rule MSDN CA1003, which suggests not to use this. Example:
  • MyEventHandler

The NUnitExtensions AccessorBase implementation should be used for testing internal classes to an Assembly. Rationale: An internal class is available for use for all components within an assembly, even if not generally available for other frameworks. It should contain sufficient test cases and have their public methods and properties tested as if it were a public class. Note: Not all features can be tested using the AccessorBase. Features that can be tested are:
  • Static and non-static types with static and non-static methods and properties;
  • Nested classes, be they static or non-static;
  • Private types returned by methods in other private types;
  • Private types used in the signature of methods in other private types;
  • Generics where the type parameters are public;
  • Private types derived from other private types.
Use overloading instead of defining default variables in the parameter list. Default arguments do not version well and therefore are not allowed in the Common Language Specification (CLS).

UML:ClassifierRole.name: IDE0028: Collection initialization can be simplified

UML:TaggedValue.value: Initial version of the coding standards, taken from various sources and experience from code reviews.

The Spell Checker Plugin from E. Woodruff should be used with the English-US or English-UK dictionary. It should be consistent throughout the project.
These checks for spelling errors in XML comments, strings presented to the user and naming of variables.

The variable naming scheme was chosen during the initial development of the Automation framework based on the .NET framework reference sources. The .NET reference sources have changed since then, these guidelines maintain some rules for historical reasons, and some more modern rules.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Define an Object for a Lock

UML:TaggedValue.value:
Generally, locks should be made on dedicated lock objects instead of data types. Rationale:
  • A lock object can be named to make clear the condition it protects. Generally a lock is named after a verb on an object, e.g. m_ReadLock on the object m_Socket.
  • If an object is ever exposed outside of the class, a client application may use that object as a lock handle. If we have our own lock object, there can be no additional side effects.
Classes that are sealed must implement Dispose without the protected method. If there are no unmanaged resources, the Dispose method does not need to call GC.SuppressFinalize(this).

This is not available in C# 7.0 and so will fail when compiling with Visual Studio 2017. The new form of specifying using within a function can significantly reduce nesting. The use of this new form would be encouraged for unit testing only, where the scope of the object is while it is being tested, and should always be disposed before the test case is finished (so as to avoid influencing other test cases running in the test suite). For production code, use the existing syntax of using. This makes it obvious the scope of the object before it is disposed. Simply converting object not disposed to have using without considering each individual case may result in new bugs / regressions.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Linquistic Irrelevant Output should use StringComparison.Ordinal[IgnoreCase]

UML:TaggedValue.value: Use the non-linguistic StringComparison.Ordinal or StringComparison.OrdinalIgnoreCase values instead of string operations based on CultureInfo.InvariantCulture when the comparison is linguistically irrelevant (symbolic, for example). Use StringComparison.Ordinal or StringComparison.OrdinalIgnoreCase for comparisons as your safe default for culture-agnostic string matching.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S3218: Rename this field to not shadow the outer class member

UML:TaggedValue.value:
A class outer class has defined a member variable, the inner class shadows this with a new declaration.
Rename, so that maintainers don't get confused about which variable is being accessed.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: IDE0017: Object initialization can be simplified

UML:TaggedValue.value: Whereever possible, prevent inputs from being null. Prevent properties on your class from being null. Rationale: Whenever a property can be null, it must be checked prior in user code for all instances of null. It is a common user mistake to not check for null, even if C# has introduced null coalescing operators, and the "Elvis" operator. If a property can never be null by design, this is one less NullReferenceException that can occur. Instead, return String.Empty for strings, provide default values for other reference types where possible. One design pattern in code is to receive inputs in the constructor of a class and then to set properties of the class appropriately. Don't allow those inputs to be null, and thus the properties also won't be null, and there is less code overall that has to check for null, making code simpler to read and potentially faster by removing unnecessary checks.

The directory structure and class structure should mirror the structure of the code under test. There should be one test class for each class under test. Namespaces of the test class should be the same as the class under test. Rationale: When adding, modifying or removing code from a class, one should be able to quickly identify where the test code is maintained. This helps the developer reduce duplicated test code and by understanding the structure of the production code, test code can be easier understood.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S3237: Use the value parameter in the event add/remove or property set declaration

UML:TaggedValue.value: Not using the value means that the accessor ignores the caller's intent which could cause unexpected results at runtime.

Name the events when closing based on the "gerund" form for the pre-event (words usually ending in -ing). Example:
  • Closing (pre-event) and Closed (post-event).

Software should use the NUnit Test Framework. Rationale: The NUnit test framework is mature, used by Microsoft in the CoreFX project and is cross platform. It also offers a much richer set of features of MSTest. It is also the default test framework for Mono on other platforms. It can be installed using nuget within your assembly. The NUnit Test Adaptor works also in the VS2013 and later Community Editions. Even though it can't be used in the desktop editions, NUnit has a test framework that runs outside of the Visual Studio IDE. The current version is 2.6.7. The 3.x versions should not be used as they're not supported natively by MonoIDE 5.1 or earlier (at the time of writing). NUnit 3.x is not backward compatible to NUnit 2.6.7. Version 2.7.0 has some minor backward compatibility issues, and should probably not be used when upgrading, instead upgrade to NUnit 3.x.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Aesthetic Rules which Should be Enabled
Separation of Managed and Unmanaged Resources

UML:TaggedValue.value: A class should not have both managed and unmanaged objects in the Dispose pattern. Classes should be created explicitly to handle unmanaged resources, and only unmanaged resources. A class that then has managed and unmanaged resources simultaneously should be rewritten to handle only managed resources, where those managed resources might have the responsibility of handling the unmanaged resource alone.
Use overloads that explicitly specify the string comparison rules for string operations. Typically, this involves calling a method overload that has a parameter of type StringComparison.
Do not throw System.Exception, System.SystemException, System.NullReferenceException, System.OutOfMemoryException or System.IndexOutOfRangeException intentionally from your own source code.

Interfaces shall be used in preference to abstract classes when the implementation is unimportant. Almost all cases should interfaces be used for public APIs. An interface is a totally abstract set of members that can be thought of as defining a contract for conduct. The implementation of an interface is left completely to the developer. Classes can inherit from multiple interfaces. Abstract classes define a partial or a full implementation, thereby encapsulating common functionality for inherited classes. It is only possible for a class to inherit from a single base class. To decide which should be used:
  • If the functionality you are creating will be useful across a wide range of disparate objects, use an interface. Abstract classes should be used primarily for objects that are closely related, whereas interfaces are best suited for providing a common contract to unrelated classes.
  • If you are designing small, concise bits of functionality, use interfaces. If you are designing large functional units, use an abstract class.
  • If you want to provide common, implemented functionality among all implementations of your component, use an abstract class. Abstract classes allow you to partially implement your class, whereas interfaces contain no implementation for any members.

Never expose fields as public.
By using properties, implementations can extend to include performance optimizations (e.g. lazy initialization) and throw exceptions on invalid input. Often properties are exposed as read only, and shouldn't be set, which can't be done with fields.
Converting from a public field to a property is a breaking change, requiring recompilation from all dependent projects.

Prefer the following types in C# over the System types
  • int over Int32
  • uint over UInt32
  • short over Int16
  • ushort over UInt16
  • byte over UInt8
  • sbyte of Int8

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S3376: Make class name end with EventArgs

UML:TaggedValue.value: Use standard naming conventions as prescribed by .NET

An example is given at: https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/kb/173738 The following prefixes for Windows forms should be used:
  • btn - Button Control
  • chk - Checkbox
  • cmb - Combobox
  • fra - Frame
  • frm - Form
  • grp - Group Box
  • img - Image list
  • lbl - Label
  • lbltxt - A Label control that usually prefixes a Text control in the tabbing order of the same name.
  • lst - List Control
  • lvw - List View
  • opt - Option Button
  • pic - Picture Control
  • prg - Progress Bar
  • tab - Tab Control
  • tvw - Tree View
  • txt - Text Control
  • mnu - Menu Item
Other prefixes are sometimes used in projects. The project should be at least consistent in the usage of the prefixes. For example:
  • but, cmd - Button
  • cbo - Combo Box
  • lstv - List View
  • pro - Progress Bar
  • rdo - Radio Button (option button)
  • tre - Tree View

A typical scenario where this occurs is tracing. Executing a trace, even if tracing is disabled, will result in a performance impact: int bytesRead = stream.Read(buffer, 0, buffer.Length); TraceSource.TraceEvent(TraceEventType.Information, 0, "{0}: Logged {1} bytes", m_Name, bytesRead); This will also result in a new array being created, and the value type bytesRead being boxed into the array. Even if the user doesn't enable tracing, this will still occur. If a lot of tracing occurs (which typically does at verbose level) one should check to see if tracing is enabled first. MSDN suggests to not use TraceSource.ShouldTrace, however no other reasonable viable alternative is found. This will speed up your code in hot paths and reduce the number of allocations required on the heap.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: IDE0052: Private member can be removed as it's never read

UML:TaggedValue.value:
Private members are assigned to, but are never read.
This indicates that code was likely refactored and old variables remained behind, and might still be used. Removing these members will simplify code.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S927: Rename parameter to match interface declaration
Colour Scheme in VS2017 and VS2019

UML:TaggedValue.value: Do not use the High Contrast colour scheme in Visual Studio. It has been observed that "fade unused code blocks and using" does not work. Changing the colour scheme to a non-high contrast scheme works as expected.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Code Analysis: Mandatory Ruleset (Microsoft Managed Recommended Rules)

UML:TaggedValue.value: The set of rules defined by Microsoft Managed Recommended Rules shall be mandatory for all projects. This can be accessed via the project properties under the section "Code Analysis". Additional rules may be specified.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S1121: Extract the assignment from this expression

UML:TaggedValue.value: SonarLint is warning that the expression is probably complicated and difficult to read Example: cbuf[--i] = (char)('0' | (v >>= 4) & 0xf); It's stating that the variable v should be extracted. It's up to the user, if readability is impacted or not. One reason to ignore this would be for code that is repetitive and repeated multiple times. Extracting this variable might increase the size of the code significantly making it larger than a screen, where what is important are the changes between each line.

Exceptions should not be used to change the flow of a program as part of ordinary execution. Exceptions should only be used to report and handle error conditions. Rationale: A common debugging technique is for applications to attach to the Domain.FirstChanceException handler. They might log exceptions in a local buffer, or write to a log file as required for later analysis as part of debugging. Raising unnecessary exceptions requires the application programmer to build in special checks to reduce log size. Raising unnecessary exceptions has therefore a real performance impact. Exceptions should not be raised, especially if it might be used within a loop. These performance impacts are often observed also when running in the Visual Studio IDE debugger, as exceptions are also caught and logged, resulting in non-release code being not debuggable due to performance reasons.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Rules Which should not be Ignored
S3881: Fix implementation of IDIsposable to conform to the DIspose pattern

UML:TaggedValue.value: Not properly implementing the Dispose pattern can result in memory or resource leaks and poor performing code.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Usage of Braces for Control Statements

UML:TaggedValue.value: Use the String.ToUpperInvariant method instead of the String.ToLowerInvariant method when you normalize strings for comparison.

This option should be disabled. The recommendation for enabling this rule is to make it clear what objects should be defined in the constructor. Dispose methods in framework code often want to set objects to null so that objects can be collected sooner, in case the user doesn't release the reference to the Framework code immediately. Having readonly properties makes this not possible. The use of readonly on Visual Studio 2015 U3 has been observed to introduce subtle bugs in the system where fields of a struct were no longer modifiable (no exception was raised, the debugger showed the value was being updated, but immediately out of context the value was lost resulting in incorrect state).

The Visual Studio IDE contains many rules implemented within the Roslyn Compiler to identify potential code errors. Many of these rules are being added as replacement for FxCop and other Microsoft analyzers.

Object Oriented Design is a design methodology, of which inheritance has a meaning. Use object inheritance to describe relationships between objects. However it is often used just for the purpose of code reuse. Reconsider the use of object inheritance if it is only for the purpose of code reuse. There are often other techniques (composition, static helper methods) that may be more suitable. Rationale: If class B derives from class A, it is said that B is an A, but A is not a B. If in the real world modelling this is not the case, then do not use Object Inheritance to describe this. Consider if there is a fundamental object and model it that way, as a user would expect, not how a programmer can reuse code which the user doesn't see anyway. So do not allow the implementation to influence the design and thus leading to confusion of the user.

Policy should be the responsibility of the upper layers of a design. Lower layers should implement functionality. Example: Maintaining a configuration file should have multiple classes:
  • Reading the file, if it fails it should indicate a failure. Defaults should not be returned as this could be considered policy
  • The class for maintaining the configuration should be different to how it is serialized, or deserialized to/from disk.
  • Creating a default configuration. The application can decide to create defaults in case of an error, but also notify the user.
  • A configuration can be broken down into smaller classes as required for separate functionality
This is not available in C# 7.0 and so will fail when compiling with Visual Studio 2017. More modern projects should use this if possible.

All public documentation shall be in English. The dialect of english shall be consistent with the project (either British en-GB or American en-US).
For example, the Automation framework uses en-US.
Sentences shall be properly terminated with a period, and grammar should generally be correct.
The language shall be clear, concise and understandable. If examples make the concept clearer, examples should be provided.

An abstract class should only have constructors that are protected. See CA1012: Abstract types should not have constructors. Rationale: Constructors on abstract types can be called only by derived types. Because public constructors create instances of a type, and you cannot create instances of an abstract type, an abstract type that has a public constructor is incorrectly designed.
Exceptions shall be public and inherit from the System.Exception object.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: IDE0069: Disposable field is never disposed

UML:TaggedValue.value: Update the implementation of the class to implement the IDisposable interface and dispose of the object in the DIspose method. This indicates a probably memory leak.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S3415: Make sure arguments are in the correct order

UML:TaggedValue.value:
Assertions in test code is comparing a value/function call against a constant. The order should be
Assert.That(variable, Is.EqualTo(constant)) Assert.AreEqual(constant, variable)
This checks that calls are as MSTest, NUnit or XUnit expect.
The project should define a file called .editorconfig, which is in the root folder. The configuration file should define the styles given in this coding standard.
Assemblies should be marked as explicit CLSCompliant(true), and methods should explicitly indicate that they are not CLSCompliant.

Coding standards for existing projects should be maintained. That is, do not rewrite large chunks of code simply because it doesn't conform to the coding standards. Adhere to the standards that are in use for that project.

Use comparisons with StringComparison.Ordinal or StringComparison.OrdinalIgnoreCase for better performance. But this should only be used in according to the other functional rules given in this section.

Following changes
  • CREQ0317: IDE0016, IDE0066, IDE1006 should be disabled
  • CREQ0321: Null
  • CREQ0324: Object Oriented Design
All options under this code analysis section should be enabled (part of Microsoft Managed Recommended Rules).

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S3459: Remove unassigned autoproperty, or set its value

UML:TaggedValue.value: A property which is private, or in a private class is defined, but never set. This could indicate a bug, or dead code.
Make exceptions serializable. An exception must be serializable to work correctly across application domain and remoting boundaries.

By using the NUnit Framework, you can also test your application software and frameworks on supported platforms without installing the IDE. Install the NUnit test application, which will work with .NET 2.0 and later.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S1172: Remove this unused method parameter

UML:TaggedValue.value: The method signature contains a parameter which is unused and the object is not publicly accessible. Rationale: Should remove unused parameters, as each parameter is pushed on to the stack. Performance code may be slightly impacted by this. On the other hand, if the code is not impacted by performance, one may want to ignore this warning stating that methods follow a particular syntax.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S2737: Add logic to this catch clause or eliminate it and rethrow automatically

UML:TaggedValue.value: Consider using Tuples in C# 7.1 when using the async programming model instead of ref or out. Rationale: Often when functions return results as a reference parameter (with the out keyword), it is because the result of the function call might return the success of the operation (to avoid unnecessarily raising exceptions). Rewriting the method to return Tuples instead can keep code compact and readable and avoid having to create "mini" structs or classes just to contain a small number of return values. Example: The following method attempts to get the branch name, with the result code indicating if the call was successful, and if so, then the name of the branch. bool GetBranch(string path, out string branch); This could be rewritten as: Task<(bool success, string branch)> GetBranchAsync(string path);

Do not use DangerousGetHandle. Rationale: A SafeHandle (and objects derived thereof) properly implement reference counting. By passing a handle retrieved using DangerousGetHandle, there is no guarantee that the SafeHandle is disposed/closed of while it is still in use due to lack of reference counting. To use DangerousGetHandle, you must use Constrained Execution Regions (CERs) properly and manually implement the reference counting with the SafeHandle.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Position of Braces for Control Statements
S3626: Jump statements should not be redundant

UML:TaggedValue.value: Auto properties should be used where ever possible. These look like a field, make code smaller and compact avoiding boiler plate code.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S1481: Remove the unused local variable

UML:TaggedValue.value: If the local variable is not used, it should be removed. This may indicate code paths that are not executed, showing errors. Compilers may optimize code so that the paths relying on this variable are removed. Use the discard variable _, to indicate that the variable isn't needed Example: Assert.That(() => {_ = new MyObject(null); }, Throws.TypeOf<ArgumentNullException>()); This example makes it clear that we're looking for an exception in test code and do not care about the object instantiated if the test should fail. Example: if (!dict.Search("input", out _, out int count)) { ... } This example indicates that only the second out parameter is required.
A call to GC.SuppressFinalize() should only occur in the Dispose method of an object.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S2589: Change condition so that it does not always evaluate to true

UML:TaggedValue.value: Where possible, the C# construct lock(object) { } should be used instead of the explicit implementation Monitor.Enter and Monitor.Exit. Rationale: The compiler knows the precise scope of the lock and ensures that the lock is always freed properly. The lock construct also ensures that a critical section's scope remains completely within a single function.

Do not use Thread.Suspend or Thread.Resume to manage your threads. Synchronize threads using WaitHandle objects and loops. Rationale: Using Thread.Suspend and Thread.Resume doesn't allow any control when a thread is suspended or resumed. It could do so in the middle of a lock, including a lock that is system wide in the framework or in the Operating System. Suspending may occur and block all other threads unexpectedly, including unmanaged locks. Also, when a thread is suspended, a call to Thread.Abort may raise an exception in .NET for WIndows, or can be simply ignored under Mono. The behavior in this case is not well defined.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: Sender in Protected OnEvent Method Signature

UML:TaggedValue.value: Related to partial classes, nested classes should be kept at a minimum. It is considered a problem when the usage of nested classes leads to source files so large that partial classes are considered. Consider using namespaces instead. One exception to this might be providing a suite of functions within a static class. The static class could be partial, while the functions themselves are considered in a single source file. However, even this case should be reconsidered if it should be instead that a single static class provides a wrapper for new internal static classes that are separated (and would therefore increase code readability).
In use cases where performance is required on multithreaded systems, the Microsoft concurrency plugins shall be used for analyzing thread and CPU core usage.

UML:ClassifierRole.name: S3973: Use curly braces or indentation with if statements

UML:TaggedValue.value: In the absence of enclosing curly braces, the line immediately after a conditional is the one that is conditionally executed. By both convention and good practice, such lines are indented. In the absence of both curly braces and indentation the intent of the original programmer is entirely unclear and perhaps not actually what is executed. Additionally, such code is highly likely to be confusing to maintainers.
